page.title: 06ORCHESTON BUTTERFLIES
page.content: It is said that sheep are responsible for the springy texture of the turf on Salisbury Plain. It is also particularly rich in the wild flowers that grow around this area. Wild Orchids are our prize exhibit and up to twenty varieties grow on the downs, some of which are rare and should{NOT} be picked because of the slow germana- tion of the seeds, which sometimes take several years to come into flower. Butterflies also thrive on our down- land and those commonly seen are: Dark Green Fritillary, Marbled White and the Small Blue. Two varieties which are exclusive in this particular part of the Plain are The Adonis Blue and The Chalk Hill Blue, whose cater- pillars feed on the Horseshoe Vetch with its tiny golden flowers.
